content:
Posted: March 11, 2013
												Mount and Blade: Warband is personally one of my favorite games.Yes, despite it's obvious low-budget production, it's still one of the best games I've played, especially for those into the Action genre, but want important RTS and RPG elements.You also gotta pay respect to the developers, Taleworlds. They didn't have much money when they started out, ( actually they almost had none ) and they started in a garage for the first game, but it slowly upgraded into this glorious masterpiece. Mount and Blade: Warband is a great game because it has a level of depth and complexity that is further developed by it's design. The combat is one of the best things about Mount and Blade: Warband, because it promotes skill, it promotes variation, and it promotes seperate playstyles. Do you like spears, swords, or what? You can literally pick from lots of different weapons, and these weapons are just copy/paste reskins. They all have another depth to that as well. Weapons do various types of damage and effects. Blunt weapons, for example, will knock enemies out in singleplayer, allow you to sell the enemy after battle to a slave trader. So you can make some money. Piercing damage weapons allows you to penetrate armor, and cutting weapons allow you to chop light armored enemies in half. You can see on the weapon's stat page what kind of stats it has. It may be a faster, but shorter weapon, or a longer and slower weapon. You may ask 'Why do I want a blunt weapon in multiplayer?' Well, for 1 reason, you can knock down people with it. As in, take them to the ground, where you can beat them silly.There are also weapons that 'aren't balanced'. This means, you can stun the enemy if they decided to block you, and if your weapon is heavier.Personally, I like the default spear. It's weak, shorter than other polearms, and not as fast as some. However, I very much enjoy the weapon because it fits my playstyle. It's a flexible weapon, one that can perform in all situations, and perform exceptionally well in open fields and against cavalry.The multiplayer for Mount and Blade: Warband is also very good. It has the standard TDM, FFA, and all sorts of things, but it also has Duel and Siege. You can duel other players in a match of skill of the blade, or you could play in large battle sieges. Some servers allow for 64v64 player sieges, which is VERY fun to play. The sieges are exactly how you would see castle defence/offense. Archers firing down to the besiegers, crossbowmen firing up to soften the defence, infantry fighting it out on the walls in a tense close quarters melee battle, and warriors emerging from the siege towers.The Singleplayer for Mount and Blade: Warband, is less about skill, and far more about being much, much smarter. You start off has a foreigner, with different stats and starting equipment, depending on the choices you make. You can also be a male or female, which DOES change which options you have available to you. You can start as a male noble, and have an easier start, as you will have most things you need, such as extra gold, renown ( for getting lords to recognize you ) and a banner ( for looking cool ). It's not like there isn't a challenge. You can start as a commoner female for a harder path if you want. The challenges are sexist, by the way, so don't get upset over nothing. If you still do, get out. Now. Anyways, if you are a female, you may have an alternate way of rising to power.As a male, you do the generic stuff. You gain renown, become a vassal ( or become another... )You court a lady you like, and battle for women and fight for their honor in tournaments.As a female, it is much different. You can talk to lords, some may even already like you, others may insult you for being a woman. You can use this to your advantage. A woman in Calradia can manipulate the balance of power by marrying into a stronger/wealthier family and in turn, using him as a means to rise into power.As for the other things in the singleplayer, there's many viable playstyles. You don't HAVE to participate in combat 24/7. Maybe you can if you want to. You can be a trader, who buys and sells and owns businesses throughout the land. You can be the plain old adventurer, doing quests for rewards, or you could be a slaver, knocking the enemy out, and selling them to the highest bitter. Of course, there are multiple playstyles available, as I said. My personal favorite is the 'Arena Hero/Tournament Champion' type style. I gain money from fighting in the arena to fund my troops, and I use my troops to help fight bandits, and fight deserters.As you get further into the singleplayer, you will eventually become a vassal. You can manage fiefs, basically plot of lands, and tax them accordingly, managing the economic state of your area by helping the place out. Towns and Villages will have different types of things to do.In towns, you will find that there is much to do. You can go to the inn, look for recruits, ask fellow travellers about things, find slavers, book merchants, and companions.( Companions are like the player, you can customize them and level them up. )There are also many merchants in town, where you can buy armor, weapons, mounts, and supplies.In villages, you can recruit peasants of the faction you are at. So if you go into faction A's village, you will recruit faction A's peasants. If another faction takes over those will still be Faction A's peasants.Also, you will need to manage morale. Being constantly defeated, being forced to surrender, leaving troops to die while you escape... Those will hurt morale. ( Low morale = Deserters )And yes, you can be beaten. There are no checkpoints. If you fail, you must suffer the consequences of your actions. But, in Calradia you don't die. That doesn't make you special though. No one else really dies, other than the generic soldier. You and every other lord are against each other, friendly or not. Like a particular lady? Better make sure Count Gutlans doesn't sweep her off her feet first. Maybe you'll have to duel him so Gutlans won't see her again.But let's say you get captured before you can get to Gutlans. You were defeated by bandits and captured. You didn't get to escape for a long, long time. The lady you like is now going to marry him. You've failed in your goal to marry her, and do you know why? It was your fault. Every action in Mount and Blade has a consequence, so making choices are important.Mount and Blade: Warband's singleplayer is an open-world sandbox. If you want, you can be an adventurer all the way until there is only one kingdom left. Yup, that's perfectly fine. There is no forced objective. You, as the player, are able to decide what you want to do, and when you want to do it. And of course, how you want to do it.Do you know if you're a top-notch fighter? Think you can take on everyone alone with your boys? If you can do it, go ahead. It's entirely possible to have a team of ultimate fighters against hordes of men.Mount and Blade: Warband's greatest strength is the use of it's module system. This allows for VERY easy mod use, you just put your mods into 'Modules' and just open the launcher, BAM. It's there. That's all you had to do.Warband's modding community has developed some incredible mods, mods which improve the game tenfold, mods which completely change the genre of the game, and mods which completely change the way the game is played in and out of itself. They aren't tiny mods that change 1 or 2 things, but legitmately, they are mods that are on par with other triple A titles themselves.In short, you can play the singleplayer, which puts hardcore players to the point, and multiplayer, which puts you at the tip of another player's blade where you battle with skill, and mods, which can completely change your experience and improve upon the base game, or put you into a world you prefer more, just Mount and Blade-y.

												I'm going to point out only the pros and cons because i have people to send to the gulag and don't have the time to write a full review, yet.Pros:-Immersive realistic medieval world;-Amazing combat system;-Large map with a good instant map creator for battles;-Excellent faction diplomacy mechanics (for an fps rpg);-Large choice of weapons and armour, that  match existing kinds of armour that existed at the time.-Ease to mod;-Excellent mechanics for creating parties and armies, with realistic modifiers such as morale, salary, etc..;-Massive battles up to 300 people at a time, with tons of bodies that stay;-Amazing siege system with victory or defeat bringing criteria such as remaining food in the city/castle, how long to build siege equipment-Doesn't require a powerfull computer;-Tons of great mods available;-No capitalist foreign intervention;-Freedom of choice relative to your history, what you do, what you become, you can shape the fait of kingdoms, drive them to be empires or erase them from history, become a dreadfull bandit or a renown lord, you can even found your own kingdom; -Good multiplayer includes servers with up to 200 slots, amazing maps and game modes, and tons of fun, especially in a clan;Cons:-Graphics;-Game instability due to the insalation of mods or add-ons;-Once you conquer Calradia there is not much else to do;-Singleplayer will get you hooked up for 200 hours before you go buy Napoleonic Wars and forget about Native;-Swadians knights=rage+frustration;-"Overpowered" weapons in multiplayer don't allow for good balance in matches, especially sieges;-Hard to learn combat since singleplayer bots play in a different style from 90% of players who won't give you a chance in the game and will constantly abuse you;-No russian bias;9.7/10 would m&b again.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												Mount and Blade: Warband is an incredible game. One of my friends recommended it to me when it was on sale for 10 bucks so I thought I would give it a try. I didn't have high expectations going in. The game gives you great D&D style rpg elements in designing your character and the ability to make your army fight how you want it to. Honestly, the more and more I play this game, the more I realize that a massive cashgrab company like Ubisoft or EA would never be able to create a game this good. It has basically endless replay value because you have no main storyline, you have a ton of freedom in deciding what you want to be doing. End game involves you declaring independence from the other factions and becoming king of your own chosen area and then waging war to unite the entire map under your rule. That's the official engame, but you never actually need to even do that to love this game.There's diplomacy, fun combat involving you and your entire army, village/town management, and a good amount of historical fiction (by this I mean the entire storyline is set in a fictional world but it is metaphorically accurate to Medieval society in the Eurasian region.) Also, I highly recommend the diplomacy mod for newcomers to the game. It adds a lot of good features that fit in perfectly and it doesn't change anything about the original game. You can grab it on the steam workshop with a single click before you start playing. (Also, there are just a lot of good mods for this game in general. Some are complete overhauls while others are minor additions.)

 Best medieval simulator	Honestly I wasn't sure what I expected when I first played Mount and Blade: Warband. I believe MB:W was made by a very small team so it's very very impressive to see what they did. I'd reccommend this game to anybody who likes medieval simulators, or anyone who likes raising their own army and leading as its commander in a Game of Thrones esque game.

Posted: March 12, 2015
												Mount & Blade is one of those rare indie games that just blows you away. I know that it’s old now, and it’s rare to find someone who isn’t at least aware of it. But why does it blow you away and why is it so highly recommended?What Mount & Blade does so well, and what lots of AAA games fail to get right – is combat. The guys who developed this got the feel of combat absolutely spot-on. Everything just feels incredibly natural. Be it horseback archery like a Mongol, bringing down a 2 handed Axe on your opponents shield or firing a Musket in the DLC. The combat is what makes this game stand out against other big-budget titles. It also makes for fantastic multiplayer. I’ve lost many an hour of my life enjoying this with my brother.But a game can’t be built on combat alone can it? The answer is that actually it can, but Mount & Blade doesn’t really on just the combat. The compelling thing that will keep you coming back to this game is the epic scale of the single player campaign. You start off as an independent noble, only able to recruit so many people into your army. You can go through life raiding caravans and villages to gain infamy, or you can join up with one of the local kingdoms and help them on their conquests. This is how you can get villages and castles given to you, and then when you go to war – you sometimes find yourself defending the estate you own. It really does make for a “just one more battle…” situation, which is why it can be so incredibly addictive if you aren’t careful.If I haven’t sold you on that. Then I would recommend you just take a look at some of the mods available for this game. There are some seriously cool Star Wars mods for example! And even though it is quite an old game, there is still stuff coming out for it even now. Give it a go, you won’t regret it.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												I've heard of this game for a long time now but never got a chance to buy and play it until last winter sale, I finally tried it, and it's an awesome game so far, worth more than what I paid for.It's a sandbox medieval RPG/tactical/strategy/empire-management game. You start out with a character, whose 'background story' can be customized, that can affect your character's starting location, equipment, stats, and reputation.You level up your character, assign stats and skills, customize his looks, equip gear and weapons, acquire followers. the battles are in real-time, similar to Chivalry and Skyrim but with more units, Imagine Total War-like battles but you get to join and command your army in battle. Once you get more known in the land, and have a lot of reputation, kings and lords might get interested in your service and ask you to join them, or maybe refuse them and found your own kingdom! or just make your own business empire and earn money the civilian way, or be a travelling merchant,. be a bandit in the wilderness raiding villages, selling prisoners to slavers, and preying on passing caravans, Many possibilities.What you do in the game depends on your choice, You can completely do almost everything you want, be a bandit, a merchant, a businessman, a mercenary, a soldier, a commander, you can even make your own faction, and conquer the whole land.Not mentioned the multiplayer is fun as well, like Chivalry but better. and the modding support is great, tons of new content to play if you somehow get bored of vanilla gameplay. Since the game is out for many years already, the game has a lot of total conversion mods already, aside from the usual mods that enhance the gameplay, there are ones that completely add new land, factions, lore and backstory, some mods adapts a popular work-of-fiction like the lord of the rings or game of thrones, or moves the game into a different era and setting, like feudal japan, roman empire, american civil war, medieval europe, etc.Luckily, I only played it recently and a sequel is coming out soon (2016), not much waiting for me. Play it now while the sequel isn't out yet, or you'd miss out on a lot of things.9.5/10

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
He stood and observed the audience with tired, almost lifeless eyes. Cleaning his throat, he started his speech:- Today it is my third day without Mount & Blade: Warband. 70... 78 hours to be precise...The audience was shocked. The silence rested in the room for few seconds until someone on the left started a timid clap, leading the rest of the room. Everybody was marvelled - how could someone start playing Mount & Blade: Warband and quit for 78 hours?! That was almost beyond comprehension.He said, with a half smile on his lips but the fatigue in his soul still clear in his eyes:- Thank you, thank you. It is hard, but I am struggling. After 3 years and a half, I believe... my brothers, I believe I will never look back.A young boy could be seen whispering in his neighbour's ears- Do you think I'll get there some day? Do you think I will manage to stop playing one day?to which the other boy replied- We can only dream... he has shown us that there is hope...The audience went nuts and clapping and shouting of joy; that's what they have been waiting for, for a hope, that that young man had just unannouncedly brought to them all. With a gesture of his hands, he urged the audience to quiet down, his life slowly coming back to him at that moment, the smile brightening up in his face, and then he said- My brothers! I am free! I shall never play Mount & Blade: Warband anylonger. I have prevailed.Filled the hearts with that hope that day, that young man has never returned the MBW Addiction Centre. Two days from that he would find out that he was very wrong - he answered the call to save Calradia, and returned to Mount & Blade: Warband, and was once again showered by the glory of the battlefield.- One does not simple stop playing Mount & Blade: Warbandhe thought. Yet this time he was almost right for that was almost the truth. None, none of them could possibly rid their lives from Mount & Blade: Warband ever again, until that day in which a greater glory would await.Until Mount & Blade: Bannerlord, their souls was bound - and they knew it.

Posted: November 3, 2016
												If you have never played a Mount and Blade game before, Warband is THE game in the series to get.With thousands of mods, from simple graphic changes, to full blown total conversions, this game has so much to offer.The game might shock you at first if you are used to playing nothing but Triple-A games that focus more on looks than gameplay, but if you stick with the slightly aged graphics and slightly steep learning curve, you will find your time is rewarded with a very open ended world where you can be and do just about anything a person in the time era could do.M&B:Warband features great single player with AI that seems like it wants to survive and thrive as much as you do. It also has a robust multiplayer engine that allows you to share the experience with others to make the game feel like it has taken you back to another era. W The game does not hold your hand nor does it favor easy wins, but it does make what you do count much more than a lot of other pretenders do.

It offered countless hours of enjoyment (litterally countless since I played the non-Steam version for a long while).Now, I've moved to the multiplayer/modding side of the game (I'm a developer for NordInvasion[nordinvasion.com]) and it continues to be one of my most played games. content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Mount & Blade: Warband is one of those classic gems which will stand the test of time for decades to come. For me, it is much like my memories of Morrowind: nothing but grand, incredible adventures and tale after tale unique only to me.As far as I know, there are no other games out there that are directly comparable to the genre of Warband. In a single game you have grand strategy, tactical combat, action hack and slash, lite city simulation and RPG all wrapped in one awesome game. Everything about it will pull you in further and further much like the “one-more-turn” syndrome experience from games like Civilization.In the briefest of summaries: you raise and command an army, and then choose how to use it. You can take over the world, marry into royalty, freelance, help overthrow a ruler, become a trading mogul, or even play politics with the warring factions. You can do just about whatever you want, and all of it is absolutely fantastic. A must buy title for sure.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												Mount & Blade: Warband is an amazing game, but I think the vanilla game is a bit too slow-paced even though that might be a good thing since realisticly no one can become a King or a Queen in a day.I do like the native version of the game, but getting captured by bandits or deserters in the early game can be a real pain in the♥♥♥♥♥and the ammount of gold you get from missions can be quite small. Of course if you get enough renown you can become a vassal, but that just means you are working under a King who wont give you towns or castles untill you have a ton of renown. (And that can take alot of time, depressingly so.)"Why did you give this game a thumps up then?"Well, there IS a thing called cheats in the options before you start the game, so that's one way to make the game more enjoyable, but you won't be able to get any achievements.I do personally perfer downloading a custom mod from the Workshop or the Mount & Blade: Warband Nexus.My personal favourite mod from the Workshop is the Vexed Native Mod by Vechs. The mod basicly speeds up the training time of troops, gives you more gold and renown from missions and adds a few more practical options into town and castle menus.In the end the Native version is a solid 8 for me, but adding cheats or a mod that helps you progress through the game faster ups it to a 10.

Mount & Blade: Warband  Field Rating Review   Graphics 6 While the game definitely does not shine in environmental textures, the differences in armor are enough to feel the satisfaction of getting new gear. The animations are also relatively smooth and intuitive.   Gameplay 8.5 With a combat system not seen in any other game, Mount & Blade sets itself apart. Ride your horse into battle and cut down your enemies at the head of your army (or small warband), meet them face to face as a footsoldier, or pick them off from afar as an archer, the choice is yours. The game maintains a classic RPG skill system which allows you to manage not only your main character, but ever other secondary character in your party. You will never have as much fun running your sword through your foes than you will in Mount & Blade: Warband.   Story N/A Honestly, there's really not much of a story to this one, as it treats itself as a "craft your own tale" sort of story. Which is perfect for their goal.  Multiplayer 6 Where the multiplayer of Mount & Blade: Warband shines is in its mods. Look into them, you will not regret it.   Replayability 9 I have played Mount & Blade since the days of its beta. And still I consistently find myself returning for more, to tell myself a new story, or to simply enjoy the unique combat once again.   Overall 7.9/10 One of the most satisfying things in gaming, to me, is starting at the bottom of the ladder and working your way up. Visually seeing the increase of strength in your character and their advancement, be it through armor, or the number of followers you have. Mount & Blade: Warband does this is spades, and it is glorious. Ever wanted to command hundreds of men? Ever wanted to have an elite small force? Ever wanted to siege castle and throw down a king? Then Mount & Blade: Warband is the game for you.With fantasticly unique combat, wonderful rpg points elements, and a great set of mods which make the game that much more extensive, you will find yourself coming back to Warband again and again. If you liked this review, feel free to check out my curator page:The TipsterYou are also welcome to join our group and play/discuss games together, here:  The Tipster

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												NOTE: Review based off non-steam version, playtime is not accurateMount & Blade Warband has terrible enemy AI, broken siege mechanics, very dated graphics, and is quite possibly one of the best games of it's kind.Never before have I seen a game that blends RPG and Real Time Strategy together in such a satisfying way. This is emergent gameplay at it's finest because it in no way limits you from choosing to play as you see fit. You can rise to become King of the entire world and unite them all, or undermine them all by playing them against one another in a never ending conflict, or ignore war altogether to become a trader, or a bandit, maybe even take over a castle as an illegitimate marauder and see how long you can hold out against the vast armies out to take it from you. You can travel with a huge army or a small group of interesting NPCs. Don't like the base setting? You can download mods to play in real world settings, or fantastical places like Westeros from A Song of Ice and Fire, or Middle Earth from Lord of the Rings.If you like sandbox games, this is it at it's finest. Does it have problems? Sure, of course it does. The saving grace however is that everything else works beautifully.COMBAT - While the AI is incredibly stupid to the point of just knowing basic "charge at you screaming" tactics and turning their back to a cavalry charge to chase one guy who broke through their lines first... the combat itself is very well done. Melee feels very intense and reactionary, you have to be on your guard at all times and be ready to take advantage of any enemy weaknesses. Archery is both deadly and difficult, and requires a serious investment for your character to be good at. Unit types are varied with no one faction sharing identical unit types. Mounted combat is the best I've ever seen in a game allowing you to use a large variety of weapons from horseback and giving serious advantage to mounted warriors. There's a lot I could say about combat but it's really got to be experienced first hand.POLITICS - With 6 main factions in the game, rival claimants to every throne, independent troops of bandits, raiders, deserters, and the like, and the possibility to even create your own separate faction, there is a ton of variety in the game. You can side with any of the factions or none of them, you can even play several off on each other if you have good relations with multiple lords. You can marry a huge number of eligible partners, as either male or female. You can even convince certain lords to defect to your own faction if they like you well enough. You can rise in influence by doing quests, conquering enemy settlements, capturing rival lords, and defending your faction's territory.SIEGE - Siege mechanics are a little lacking, you will only ever have one ladder (which is really a ramp) or one siege tower for any castle siege, the AI again is very basic, the archers fire from a distance but all melee and cavalry units (who dismount for the siege) just clambor up single file to the top of a wall to fight a war of numbers against a swarm of bunched together units at the top. You can issue commands to pre-defined groups (Archers, Melee, Cavalry, Etc.) to tell them where to go, what kind of weapons to use, and so on, but by and large the sieges aren't the biggest highlight though they are still incredibly intense due to awesome combat mechanics.ROLEPLAY - While there is an element of backstory and lore to this world, mostly explored through your companion's musings on areas, by and large the world is very open for interpretation. The six factions are based off real-world equivalents like the Cossacks, Mongols, Arabs, Vikings, and Gauls both in terms of unit types and archtitecture. Roleplaying shines however in how it allows you to be whoever you want to be. You can choose to start as a lord with enough honor to have your own banner sigil, or start as a lowly thief who just runs about burning villages and trying to keep one step ahead of the law as you try and make it rich. There's so many variables that let you choose how to play the game, you can even solo the game if you want for a true challenge. There are a lot of unique stats and skills you upgrade independently that affect everything from your persuasion attemps, battle tactics, map speed, weapon skill, and the size of your army.ACTIVITIES - Aside from combat, there are quest opportunities available in villages, towns, and from other lords who ask favors. There's maybe only 10 types of quests, that range from delivering trade goods, cattle steering, bandit hunting, village defense, soldier training, attacking enemy settlements, or capturing rival lords. In addition to this there are arenas and tournaments that allow you to bet on yourself as you fight in a host of games. Upgrading buildings in towns and villages you own. Exploring towns and castles. Attending feasts. Recruiting and training units. There's always SOMETHING to do.Bottom line, if you haven't played this game yet and you are even remotely interested in RPGs or RTSs then you need to get it now!

Posted: April 26, 2016
												I'm quite a fan of games that let you do what you want. This game is the prime example of that. It doesn't hold your hand and you are plunged right into the middle of a war-torn land with naught but some clothes and a blunt sword. Warband gives such a sense of accomplishment like when you defend your first castle from 1000 madmen with crossbows and pikes with only a handful of your elite men.When I say you can do anything, I mean you can become an infamous bandit that everyone hates, including other bandits, you can be a noble and loyal knight or lord, a humble merchant or a godlike king. Commanding your armies in battle is one of my favourite features. One criticism is that it's too easy to take advantage of the AI though. The game isn't too hard to pick up, but takes quite a bit of time to master the mechanics to be fully efficient at conquesting through the lands of the filthy swadians.Did I mention there is multiplayer? If you do happen to find a server with a respectable amount of people, you will die. A lot. Because I'm bad, I keep away from online.Also, all I've been reviewing is the base game. There are plenty of overhauls that, after 500 hours and counting, I haven't even touched. That should be a hint at how much replayability Warband has (if you manage to stick to one character for long enough).If you like games, Warband is for you.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												When I got this game, it was on sale. After purchasing it for a low price, I felt like I had cheated the company. This game exceeded my expectations, as I generally am under the impression that lower graphics might dampen a game.Mount & Blade: Warband, however, has become an addiction, and I feel like I would choose it over Skyrim.I have not played the previous Warband game, so I cannot tell you if this is better or worse, and I do not intend to quote a wiki page on features that this game has or doesn't has in comparison.But, I can tell you my personal opinion on it.Graphics+Good rendering. Not the top quality textures, but you are frequently in the midst of battle with a lot of models going at once, so "ultra high def" would probably obliterate the normal computer if it was an option.+Simple and sweet to make it flow just right and still feel amazingly immerisve.+Some extra graphic options to give it a better feel, they can be turned on or off via the menu.-Character design just feels a bit ugly to me, whether it be the low poly graphics simply just my personal taste, but either way, don't expect to design a "hawt" character like in Skyrim.-Also your character's hair disappears immediately under a helmet, even if it's Norwegian-metal-band long. But that's just a pet peeve.Combat+The combat is great, seriously.+Easy to grasp combat system, where you literally just click and move your mouse/slide your trackpad to wherever you want to swipe. Same goes with blocking.~It might be a bit awkward with the throwing weapons and bows, or I'm just really bad at it. You decide.+Horse combat is so fluid and almost realistic, there is something just so... lovable about it.-I cannot say the same for castle/city battles. It is best to just leave your soldiers go to battle without you, because otherwise, you get cramped going up the ladder/seige tower and it just messes up the flow and a lot of unnecessary lives are taken by the clutter. It could honestly be so much better. This is probably my top con for the game.Story+Open world, meaning, you don't have to worry about following the story 24/7.~Not a lot of "trails of breadcrumbs." Take this as you will based on what you look for in a game. +It has a vague goal, to conquer Calradia, which you can play years without ever having to do.+There are so many ways to play the game, making it fun to play no matter your intention or strategy.+Your character's backstory will affect their starting items and social standing.+Historically correct as it can be, with characters who are religious/superstitious, oppression of women (In game, of course. Don't try to call the developers misogynists, they are 100% aware of the game's female oppression because it is in the sake of accuracy. Many characters will accept female characters, I found.)+100% Replayability. You can make hundreds of characters to try out all the options and combinations, join any of the various factions, and take different approaches to the making of your own faction.[h2]General Gameplay[/h2]+Overall, it's an amazing game.+I love the faction system. Making it takes a lot, and it makes it all the more rewarding.+Comprehensive companion system, which are vital to the game if you intend on making your own faction.'-I'm not to fond of losing my vassals' relationship points by four because he doesn't have fiefs, particularly when we don't have fiefs to give. It would be more realistic if it took less points, because who complains about not having fiefs when there's none to give?-At least remove it from the husband (unsure if it's the same with wife). Who gets so mad about not having fiefs when their wife is ruler?-The AI of parties on the map when they have a relationship with you could be better. For instance, I chased my husband's party (which was faster than me, while I had a larger party) all the way to a corner of the map because he was a part of an enemy faction and that was the only way I could get him to talk to me so I could get him to join our faction. +None of those cons really tamper with game play all that much, they are just annoying. However, you can lose vassals by not giving them fiefs regardless of how much they loved you. But maybe it was meant to be like that.In the end, I give it 9.5/10. It has its awkward features here and there, but in the amount of time I played over the course of a few days, I loved it. I hope you love it too. Moral of the story, is never let graphics deter you from a game. You might miss an amazing experience.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2013
												Mount and blade warband is a unique game. You will find non other like it. It has potential to be great, and it does just that, but there are a few things you should note before deciding to pick it up yourself. I will tell you everything I know, as I've played countless hours of the game and basically achieved everything you can learn within the game. So, lets get started.First off, the game will be confusing if you have just started. You think there is a campaign, quests, or something to guide you? There is not. You have the power to go wherever you want, join whatever you want, and be whoever you want. The game does not decide anything for you, you decide it yourself. Starting off can be hard, like really hard. So hard, you probably will rage quit if you do not know what to do. The early game has bandits, Looters, Outlaws that will chase you down and take your prisoner. To counter this, you can raise an army by going to a nearby town and recruiting villagers. Note, these villagers are not good. You will have to upgrade them to win, and the start of the game will depend on you, and rarely the troops you have. There is a total of 5 different factions, and you get to choose which ones you will join, ally with, or seige war with. All the factions have different troops, weapons, and soldiers to make the game more unique. Some have better infantry, others archers, or calvery. Then you have companions which tag along side with you. They will never die, but can be wounded, upgraded, and you have the choice of what their stats will be, and what they are equipped with. Overall, companions are really good once you get them to the point where they help with fighting, and give you an additional point in skills. If they have +3 in Surgery, that will combine with your +2 to make a total of +5. They are helpful, and are recommded.Being a vassal to a kingdom is where the game starts to get intense. You get assigned a random fief(Town, castle, or a city) in which will pay you a weekly tax. Note, castles do not pay anything, only a place to store troops at and keep your council members. Being a vassal to a king, you will get to join military seiges. The marshal to the faction will send you a message to gather some troops and join him in a march to fight the enemy. If you decide to join, your relation with the faction and marshal will go up.That brings us to relationships. This can be a pain. You normally start of with your relationship with everyone set at 0. To make it go up, you will have to ask for tasks you can fulfill. Every task you take, the relationship goes up by +1, and rarely +2. Every time you get your relationship up 20 points, the lord will change relationships with you. Friend, Trustworthy, Devoted, etc. The more he likes you, the better the odds of persuasion, Marrying their daughter, owning more fiefs, and more.To own a fief, the king grants you it. They usually seek vassals without any fiefs, or their friends. That is why relationships with a lot of lords will help.Marrying a daughter to a lord will improve your status a lot. It also gives more diplomatic options in your council, which is located at your castle or small town. Note, not many women like to marry a man without a castle or city. Don't mix a City with a town. A town is a small, poor village. A city has a market, etc. To continue, to make a women like you, you will have to speek to them and click the option, "I am your admiror" or something like that. That will either benefit you, or quite the opposite. Then she will send you a letter every 7 days to come visit her. Visit her until you get a relationship of 25+, then you ask to marry her.Renown is the amount of lords that talk about you. Getting this up will help you get more known, which causes people you've never even met like you. You can get this up by fighting bandits, defeating enemies, marrying, etc.Honor affects your interactions with other lords and causes certain events. A high honor can increase the likelihood of a mercanary accepting an offer, or of you being elected as marshall. Lords will like you for having positive honor, and every 3 points in honor will increase relationships by +1. Lower honor can result in a bounty on your head, or a war being declared on your faction.Right to Rule is, well. Self explanitory. If you have a low right to rule, do not start your own faction. This will result in every kingdom to think you are an outlaw, "Not worthy enough to own a kingdom" and will declare war on you. Start your kingdom when it reached about 80.Starting your own faction is, well. Kind of easy actually. Its for a late game, when you've married, and have become lasting allies with another faction. Once you want to start your own faction, you have to go rogue. Break up your alliance with your current kingdom, and attack an enemy. Take the castle, and you will have the option to choose a flag/banner. You basically are your own king, and can hire vassals, or make your companion a vassal. To make a companion a vassal, talk to them and give them a fief. They will isntantly leave your army, make their own, and assist you in war. You can also persuade other lords into joining your own. You need to have the persuasion skill, and they need to have problems with their current king before you can have them switch over.From then on, you basically conquer all of the map. Thats very late, late end game. The overall singleplayer can last hundreds of hours, which is why this game is unique.Overall, the game is amazing, and is well worth it in my opinion, and I recommend it to everyone who loves roleplaying. Mods are very, very recomended. The base came comes flat with not many diplomatic options. I will recommend some mods for you to try, as they will enhance gameplay by a lot. I don't even play the base game anymore as it's very, blah.A Clash of KingsFloris ExpandedFull Invasion 2 (Multiplayer only)You can find them all here http://www.moddb.com/games/mount-blade-warband/mods

												This game is perfect. It says I played 250+ hours, but I played many, many more before I used steam.You can command your own army in person and have to actually deal with the problems of logistics, food and your own gear. Now, one point is the graphics, they're really good for an indie game (made by a man and his wife) but you're going to need to mod it up a bit if you're a real graphics addict. The gameplay makes up for it ten times though!The mods are actually a great part of the game. You have tons of them, varying from massive overhauls which completely change the financial system and more, to mods that just add some extra gear and graphics. There is so much variety. The modding community is just huge. Some mods that I really enjoyed:- Prophesy of Pendor (complete overhaul, new map, factions, lore, units and many more)- Blood in the West (lord of the rings)- Floris mod expanded (an enchancement of the current gameplay)- Gekokujo (Samuraaaiii)It's 66% off now, BUY IT. They're also making Mount & Blade Bannerlord (sequel) at the moment, and expecting it this fall I think. So get used to the game and excite yourself for: https://www.taleworlds.com/en/Games/Bannerlord/Media

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Charge into battle. Ride into legend. This non-expensive sandbox masterpiece brings together the opportunity to do anything, from being a sellsword bandit mercenary trader to a kingmaking politic-intrigued warband-leading vassal, into strange places such as Calradia's three bickering kingdoms, its adjacent horseloving khanate and the neighbouring haughty sultanate. This game is full of surprises as battlefields change depending on your map's terrain and your party's location.Inspiring one of the largest modding communities, Mount & Blade holds a great module system which prevents mod conflicts unlike other games (ahem BGS) and lets you fall on your knees to worship the old gods. You could go on an adventure into 1257 where religious war spreads its flame throughout the middle east and engulfs eastern europe, where the golden horde still scours for tribute in places where no king is seated, and where blood and steel would make a peasant into one of his lordships. This module would be one of my personal favorites.Of course I've left out one of many people's favorites, the multiplayer of Warband. Whether it be cRPG, Napoleonic Wars, or just the native module, the multiplayer experience is enjoyable. Personally, I'm not a big fan of the multiplayer (probably because I don't have anybody to play with) since there are always other games when I want to be competitive. Therefore, I won't say much on multiplayer.Are you still reading this? Man, you either must be really bored or really skeptical. I would have bought this game right off the bat after I read the words "non-expensive sandbox" but you know, that's just me. If you're into medieval galore, this game is a must buy. If you love sandboxes or maybe games which allows you to build armies and lead them into battle, this game is definitely for you. If you're into steampunkish or cyberpunkish games like the bioshock series and the fallout series respectively, then this game might not be for you. But who knows? You might like it.

content:
Posted: February 23
												Mount & Blade: Warband is without a doubt one of the best RPGs ever made if not the best. This game should honestly not be as good as it is. The graphics are ugly and the animations are strange and stiff yet it owns it. What do you do in this game you might ask? Anything. What do you mean by anything you may ask? ANYTHING! Do you want to be an infamous raider who enslaves villagers and sells them into slavery? You can. Do you want to be a merchant who travels from one place to another selling goods in an everchanging amazing economy system? You can. Do you want to be a King who destroys all other competetion and controls everything? You can. This game's freedom is what makes it truely amazing. This game's lack of story is it's story. Every playthrough is like an entirely different game, not one playthrough or experience will be the same. The combat is great, the mix between action and strategy is genius, the economy system is realistic and can be changed and influenced dynamically by the player or NPCs, the character creation is great. This game is truely a treat for any RPG fan, especially those who love to roleplay and immerse themselves into a world. You can be anything and do anything. And with the abundance of mods for this game that is especially true. Conversion mods such as the Lord of The Rings ones, Game of Thrones, Warhammer. Even people with a new and original world such as Perisno and Pendor are all great. And the game's expansions are amazing, Viking Conquest adding a new humongous map that takes place in our world during the Viking age, Viking Conquest adds so much and is an impressive and great expansion. Posted: February 15, 2012
												I think it's the most perfect medieval game on the market. Mount&Blade is....well, what is it?? It's an RPG, that's one thing it is, and feels sandboxy a bit, in the good way. It's an RTS, but it also makes your character apart of the action as a commander, or whatever you want. I'd say it's accurate to call it a Medieval simulator too. Mount&Blade is probably one of those games which I longed to play for years but never knew about. When I found out, I was enthralled, BEWILDERED!! I loved it more than I thought I would and can easily wrack up hours playing it. Field battles, sieges, RTS-like map, your own RPG character put into it all. The combat system is my favorite thing about it, and the multiplayer element Warband gives has become a replacement to the time spent on my favorite FPS games.GET WARBAND. It is NOT an expansion and you do no need Mount&Blade #1 to play it. It has literally everything M&B has, along with everything you wish it had. PLAY THIS GAME PLZ!Furthermore, the game has an extremely wonderful community on the developer (Taleworlds) forums. These forums also has a HUGE list of full-conversion to small mods. A singleplayer game in Warband can take anywhere from around 100 to 150 hours (if you rush it, that is). The mods will extend that tenfold. Bored of Medieval? Turn it into the old west. Or the British Isles in the Dark Ages. There is so much time and joy Warband will give you especially with these mods. As well as captivating multiplayer. Not convinced about Warband? I encourage you to read lots of reviews where I could not do it justice, and PLAY IT!! I don't know what the demo is, whether it's lame or not, but maybe you can give that a try too.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												To be frank, this is probably the best RPG I've played in a long time. Even though I'm a newcomer to the Mount & Blade series, I had and still have a blast with this game. For one: the singleplayer. I love how there's a simple foundation of a story and it leaves you to write the rest of it by playing the game. There's more to the game than just killing enemies: politics, espionage, romance, and more are all things you can do in-game. It's suprisingly immersive, given its so-so graphics and music. The one problem I have with the singleplayer game is that the learning curve is pretty steep and can scare off noobs like me. Push through and learn as you go, and it'll all be worth it. Trust me.The multiplayer, while I don't play it as much, is pretty good. You've got your standard FPS game modes in addition to Battle (one life per person) and Siege (where attackers try to take over an enemy castle). The already fun combat system is taken up to an eleven in just about any game mode here.While Mount & Blade: Warband suffers from poor graphics and a sharp learning curve, it'll still sap away your precious time in either single or multiplayer, and not in a bad way.On the scale of -10 to +10, Mount & Blade: Warband earns a 6 (Excellent).

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Ok, well first of all go ahead and buy the game before reading any further because this is one of the best freaking games I have ever played!Pros----------Tons of featuresUnique really fun styleEndless ammounts of mods to make the game how you wan't itEasily one of the most fun singleplayer experiences I have ever hadVanilla has tons of features so expect plenty of time with the vanilla before you need to rely on modsFun regimental battles in Napoleonic Wars however this has it's own flaws (see below)Cons-----------------Multiplayer lacks a co-op mode which is a huge shame since the singleplayer campaign is the best part of the gameVanilla game becomes pretty dull and you end up relying on modsMultiplayer is very repetitive and gets dull quickly with no ranking system or unlockable gear so what you see is what you getRegimental battles or Line Battles are epic at first glance with up to 200 players participating, however it is very repetitive and gets pretty dull, and also the game isn't tooled for it. What I mean by that is that there is no voice chat in-game, therefor a regiment requires an external communication program such as Teamspeak, and having to download extra stuff discourages alot of people, another flaw in this is that you have to host or buy a Teamspeak server, which can prove to be a pain in it's own right, and then there is also the matter of hosting the in-game server, which does not have a simple "click and start" system. So starting a regiment is a HUGE pain! And on top of that it's really hard finding people for your regiment if you want to start one. Multiplayer would be a lot better if people didn't have to rely on regiments to have realistic-ish battles with organized units of men. I say realistic-ish because most events also have stupid rules that make the game seem pretty linear, like no crouching, no taking cover, no firing out of line. It gets kind of annoying.Summary--------------If you get this game get it for the singleplayer! If you wan't a multiplayer medieval battle game just get Chivalry: Medieval Warfare. However don't forget the epic regiment battles in Napoleonic Wars! It is fun but trying to start your own regiment is a pain and simply not worth it. So DO NOT get this game for the multiplayer, the true beauty lies in it's unique singleplayer!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												One of my most favorite games ever. If you don't believe me, check my hours. This game is the greatest sandbox rpg ever created in my opinion. It starts slow and difficult, but if you stick it out, it becomes a wide open playground of infinite possibilities. Want to start an army of mercenaries who lay waste to villages for plunder? Go for it. Want to become the head general in your favorite army and lead assaults on enemy castles? Power to ya. Want to betray your kingdom and start your own faction and conquer the lands of your old friends?They even added marriage in this one. You can marry into power by wooing members of the opposite sex and or move up the ranks by gaining favor with the lords and ladies of the land. I began courting a woman that I met at a royal feast before I had gained any power. As a result, I invoked the ire of her father, who did not approve of a man who had no power or land. What ensued was secret courtship, a dual with the man she was in line to marry, and the long hard fight to gain her father's approval.This game is not for everyone, but it is certainly for me.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												Alright, you've bought the game. You're ready to learn! You go to the trainer, he teaches you how to fight. Done with that noise, time to play! Alright, but first the Merchant of X wants you to help you learn about quests. No problem, we can do it. Okay! Time to venture out to the big open world, and OH MY GOD! I'M BEING ATTACKED BY FIFTEEN BANDITS! ME AND MY SIX PEASANTS ARE NO MATCH FOR THEM! You're captured, they drag you along until you suddenly escape. Freedom at long last! You have no damn idea where you are! Where's Praven? Where did all this sand come from?! You wander into the nearest town's tavern. You see alot of interesting folks. Books? I can't read! Poems? I'm not a hippie! Mercenaries? I'm broke! But then you meet a robed monk. His name is Jeremus. He wants to join for free! But you need money. I'll just get a quest from the local Guildmaster. Escort cattle? That's easy! Wait, where are they going?! WE NEED TO GO TO DURQUBA, COME BACK HERE! You chase them back to Praven somehow. Then you realize you had no idea where Durquba was anyway. What's this, a tournament in Praven, win money, and fame? Fighting equally in teams? OH GOD I HAVE NO IDEA HOW TO USE A LANCE! WHY DID I DO THIS? Oh, I won. I have money! I'm going to buy all the peasants I can! Come peasants let us go and teach these bandits a lesson! They won't get the best of me this time!And suddenly I'm alone in the desert again! All the peasants are dead, Jeremus left for smarter idiots to follow, and I have no idea where the cattle went. I guess I'll just start again at the nearest ci- I'M BEING MUGGED, OHSHI- and there goes all my money. I might as well see what villages have to offer beyond fodder.Train? Me? You want me to train peasants? OKAY! Let's get down to business, to defeat the bandits! This is taking too long, I wonder when they'll atta-Oh. They're attacking now. Well... I guess I better be ready to die this time... Wait, all the peasants beat the bandits this time? HUZZAH! I must continue this streak of good luck! I'm going to lead my new peasant army to victory! They're no longer peasants. They're actual soldiers nows! Every bandit under the sun fears me! I AM INVINCIBLE! What's this in this town? Join the feast? Well why not... Wow! Look at all these lords! King Harlaus wants me to join his Kingdom? Why not! I'm a strong, capable leader, with a fierce army! War against the Vaegirs? We'll smash 'em! I'll kill every single one to death! Th-th-three hundred troops? OH LORD, WHAT DID I GET MYSELF INTO, I CAN'T FIGHT AN ARMY OF THREE HUNDRED BY MYSELF! My whole army is dead. Jeremus is dead. I am nearly dead. My horse is nearly dead.But I press on! They can't catch me, I AM TOO FAST FOR THEIR SWORDS! I'll just keep running along them until I kill all 300 of them! It will be tough, but I know I can do it. But I spoke too soon. They drag you to a keep. There are other lords stuck there too. But you manage to escape! You must rescue the other lords. You sneak in, armed with only a pole you knock out the guards! You and your fellow lords escape to safety! You're a hero of the Swadians! Our lord has called another feast! I bet it's for me, because I'm so awesome. I single-handedly defeated and capture the whole Vaegir army and killed them all. I am the deadliest thing at the feast. Not even the butter could conquer the Vaegirs with only a single arrow. War with the Rhodoks? Bu-but I just got back from the war with the Vaegirs! I've had enough of this!Taking what little King Harlaus has given me, I start my own Kingdom. What little friends I have follow with me! I'm the King of my very own Kingdom! All the trees, peasants, and snow is mine! Wait,  rule? I have to set up a government? Why did I do this! I just want to kill♥♥♥♥♥♥and get rich, I don't want to be a politician! I just want to sell rocks and sticks for money!Money, wait, you can buy businesses? Why didn't I know about this! I'll buy all the most expensive businesses, in every city! Look at all that money! Money money money money! I'm going to buy the most expensive things from now on. Only the most expensive things, nothing of the poor things. I shall only sell the most expensive things. What's this, trade prices? SELL VELVET FOR 300 MORE AT DHIRIM YOU SAY!? WHY DIDN'T I KNOW ABOUT THIS EITHER?But suddenly while playing you realize something. The sun is rising outside your window. How long has it been? When did you start playing? Why do your eyes hurt? It's been 16 hours. You've been here, questing, fighting, and failing for 16 hours. But it's okay. You don't need stoves to turn off, pets to feed, or relationships to maintain. You have Mount & Blade: Warband. Mount & Blade: Warband will always love you.

												M&B: Warband is unique in so many ways, you truely just start with a few gold coins, some weapons and thats it. From there you have to build your way to power. All over the world which is not as easy as it sounds.This game is not a game you buy due to amazing graphics or amazing sound, it is a game you buy for it´s dept and for the fun of leading grand armies to major battles and seige battles.I can honestly say after over 1000 hours. I havent won the game (yet), always made a mistake or didnt capture enough castles or even worse got to many and didnt have the men to defend them after. It is a game that has a deep connection with the middle and dark ages.Mount & Blade will live for a long long time and there are amazing mods being made all the time that adds to the quality of the game even better are the online communities/forums where you are always welcome.A couple mods I really enjoy and enhance the basic gameplay are:Floris Mod Pack - http://www.moddb.com/mods/floris-mod-packWarband battle size - http://www.nexusmods.com/mbwarband/mods/1761/The DLC is great if you love the time period and maybe join a regiment and act out the role of a soldier during those times in online events.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Well so far, I have played a couple of hours and I have to say one thing "Why did they mess with the combat system?" It worked fine in the older game, this new one kind of bites. Mounted combat is awful now and if you dont have a slashing weapon you are gonna be in for rough game. Tournaments are pretty rough as it feels like they focus on you.  I am gonna play some more but so far the improvements dont seem to be worth it.After playing the game more and getting more use to the changes, I guess I was a bit harsh but I still think the mounted combat changes were totally not a positive. It did improve the ability to attack foot troops from the mounted stationary position but the smoothness of the older system was, in my opinion, superior. Slashing weapons are a must for mounted combat. The upside to the changes were more armor and weapon choices, one more faction, more interactive npcs, more aggressive AI, more challenging tournaments, more quests, and slightly better graphics.Nearing 200 hrs now and after modding the game with the Floris mod (which isn't on steam's list) I have to say this game now rocks. The Floris mod makes the game so much more fun that it ever was. Lots of upgrades and changes. The clunky mounted combat issue was fixed, now I don't have to have slashing only weapons to enjoy it.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												This is an interesting game. Its a role-playing storyline where you customize a guy, that'll get to go from town to town, battling guys, getting a following, etc.While the graphics, and battles are great, there are some issue's: controls are pitiful, in storymode, press backwards, you'll keep going backwards till you press the forwards button, usually a couple times. Riding a horse is cool...until you keep running into walls, stalls, citizens, etc. in battles, the controls say press the X key to toggle weapons. By pressing the X key, my guy does absolutely NOTHING. The fighting controls are simple and confusing at the same time. Left mouse button attacks, right mouse button defends. Simple. The confusing part is, attacking from the side. Want to do a left-side attack? Hold the left mouse button and move the mouse left. Often miss's. To perfect it, or at least make it good enough to do damage in battle, its gonna take HOURS of practise. Crossbows and bows, while can be handy, except I never killed a single guy in a custom battle!On the bright side, battles are really good to watch. Feels medieval like.Oh and one last issue. DO NOT BUY if your computer has a couple already big games installed. Will cause some lag, and may cause computer to act strange(like mine is) while this game aint for me, its worth at least trying. If I had to recommend other games similar, I'd suggest Medieval Kingdoms: Total War, for the medieval fighting.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												WB is a game I can get caught up in for hours.  The dynamic AI is really challenging, devs did a great job with the economy. It can seem a little grindy for your first two levels, since unless you get to level 4 or 5 in the arena, you will be smoked running into bandits outside of town. And building up your reputation and friendships can take aggesss, but once you are at a high level and able to get allies to join your fights and get land and start companies in towns, things get really interesting. So much thought went into the perceived difficulties of lordship, managing your army and treaties with warring states. Graphics are dated of course but the fighting system surprisingly holds up well over time.  And although you can upgrade your fiefs with certain buildings, it would be nice to see them look more dynamic on the map. The community has done amazing things in the steam workshop!8.5/10

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												Mount & Blade: War band plays like a modern indie game. Not so well polished graphically, game play, or in general but it keeps on bringing you back for more.With Vinilla providing 6 faction, each representing empires from  medieval times and diversity in units and combat formation it reminds me of Total War RTS combat assuming you are the general and charge into to battle without having a major risk of possibly dying.Story wise is there isn't any worth noting. You are your own story. You can either serve for a king and become a warlord with castle.under your name, betray your kingdom by taking out the king and becoming it's ruler, or forge your own kingdom and dominate the land. The story is only as effective as your army power to do it however. From the get go you can start your own kingdom if you have enough man to start a war with an faction. Mission can get repetitive but all of them are optional.ProsDiverse factions, weapons, and unitsMusic is fittingNot too hard to pick up and playProgression is satisfyingConsGraphics feels datedCombat is wonkyWar is a must to survive in this game.In all in all I can truly recommend this gameMSRP: $19.99Recommend pick up price: $19.99

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												I'm quite a fan of games that let you do what you want. This game is the prime example of that. It doesn't hold your hand and you are plunged right into the middle of a war-torn land with naught but some clothes and a blunt sword. Warband gives such a sense of accomplishment like when you defend your first castle from 1000 madmen with crossbows and pikes with only a handful of your elite men.When I say you can do anything, I mean you can become an infamous bandit that everyone hates, including other bandits, you can be a noble and loyal knight or lord, a humble merchant or a godlike king. Commanding your armies in battle is one of my favourite features. One criticism is that it's too easy to take advantage of the AI though. The game isn't too hard to pick up, but takes quite a bit of time to master the mechanics to be fully efficient at conquesting through the lands of the filthy swadians.Did I mention there is multiplayer? If you do happen to find a server with a respectable amount of people, you will die. A lot. Because I'm bad, I keep away from online.Also, all I've been reviewing is the base game. There are plenty of overhauls that, after 500 hours and counting, I haven't even touched. That should be a hint at how much replayability Warband has (if you manage to stick to one character for long enough).If you like games, Warband is for you.

												This is an interesting game. Its a role-playing storyline where you customize a guy, that'll get to go from town to town, battling guys, getting a following, etc.While the graphics, and battles are great, there are some issue's: controls are pitiful, in storymode, press backwards, you'll keep going backwards till you press the forwards button, usually a couple times. Riding a horse is cool...until you keep running into walls, stalls, citizens, etc. in battles, the controls say press the X key to toggle weapons. By pressing the X key, my guy does absolutely NOTHING. The fighting controls are simple and confusing at the same time. Left mouse button attacks, right mouse button defends. Simple. The confusing part is, attacking from the side. Want to do a left-side attack? Hold the left mouse button and move the mouse left. Often miss's. To perfect it, or at least make it good enough to do damage in battle, its gonna take HOURS of practise. Crossbows and bows, while can be handy, except I never killed a single guy in a custom battle!On the bright side, battles are really good to watch. Feels medieval like.Oh and one last issue. DO NOT BUY if your computer has a couple already big games installed. Will cause some lag, and may cause computer to act strange(like mine is) while this game aint for me, its worth at least trying. If I had to recommend other games similar, I'd suggest Medieval Kingdoms: Total War, for the medieval fighting.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												absolutely great medieval rpg.   Singleplayer is openworld, and allows you to do practicaly anything you want.  Wanna be a bandit and raid trade caravans?  go ahead.  Lead a band of mercenaries in service of a lord or king.  even become a trader and make great profits trading across caladria.  Later in the game you can become the vassal of one of the many kings in the land, or even form your own nation and try to conquer caladria.  Multiplayer is fun, with game modes like Siege, Team Death Match, Deathmatch, and Duel.  Gameplay:the combat is challenging.  There are 4 directions in which one moves the mouse to either block or attack.  There is also feinting, as well as a chambering mechanic (think riposte).   It is difficult to get used to, however practice makes perfect.  Singleplayer campaign likewise has a very steep learning curve and it will take quite a while before understanding how to properly go about things  (that being said, i played/still play at allies/self take full damage, with manual block.  using easier settings will make the game alot easier to progress.)   Multiplayer consists mostsly of learning how to fight properly, since opponents are much more skilled than the singleplayer AI.  Graphics, nothing impressive, but they do the job.  There are mods that add better textures.Replaybility: If you can get used to the combat system, the multiplayer will give you tons of hours of playing.  The singleplayer campaign is also quite fun, and has hours of gameplay provided you get around the steep learning curve.  Now, the biggest thing that adds replayability to this game (and any pc game really) are the mods.  there are SOOOOOO many mods out there, from Game of Thrones conversions to Lord of the Rings.  wanna lead House Stark to victory over Joffrey (screw him), now you can with mods like A Clash of Kings.   Alot of mods add alot of new features, like being able to serve directly in a king or lords army.   Furtheremore, some mods do have a sizable multiplayer behind them.  Especially mods like Full Invasion, which allows you to fight hordes of AI with other players.  at the very least, get Floris Mod Pack, which significantly improves the standard SP experience.  Music:  Decent, nothing spectacular or horridOverall, its worth a buy.  Its not for everyone, specially since the learning curve is quite steep.  if in doubt, get it on sale, when its like 5 bucks or something.   i'd give it a... lets see here.... i'll go with a 8/10

												Well so far, I have played a couple of hours and I have to say one thing "Why did they mess with the combat system?" It worked fine in the older game, this new one kind of bites. Posted: December 8, 2015
												This game was the reason I became a PC gamer. Before being introduced to this game I was a console fanboy and played minecraft on occassion. It was not until I was introduced to this game that I fully understood what was all possible. I started off by joining a regiment in Napoleonic Wars called 34e. This regiment stayed active for I think around 6 months or some where near that. It was some of my best experiences to date. I met friends in that unit and through this game that I have played with ever since. After NW was overplayed for myself, I switched to Persistent World. That brought a whole new world of possiblities. Learning about medieval times in history and actually participating in it was a whole new experience. It allowed me to act out what had always interested me, along with allowing me to join some factions to ultimately meet some pretty amazing people. I have spent maybe 400 hours playing NW, 500 hours playing PW if not more, and around 100 hours for native. While this game lacks some graphic capabilities, the game play makes up for it all. If you are even remotely interested in history or fantasy games/movies I would recommend this game and the thousands of mods out there ready for consumption. All and all, amazing game and cannot wait till bannerlord.

												"Arcade Medieval Game"This Game has everything for a Medieval-periode-time lover❤.Weapons with historical accuracy, armour, horses and gear that is medieval themed. (mods also affect gear & Etc)Singleplayer: Roleplaying is key here, it's got good in-game history with many different factions and Warbands to play with and fight for or against. content:
Posted: April 3, 2013
												Mount and blade warband is a unique game. You will find non other like it. It has potential to be great, and it does just that, but there are a few things you should note before deciding to pick it up yourself. I will tell you everything I know, as I've played countless hours of the game and basically achieved everything you can learn within the game. So, lets get started.First off, the game will be confusing if you have just started. You think there is a campaign, quests, or something to guide you? There is not. You have the power to go wherever you want, join whatever you want, and be whoever you want. The game does not decide anything for you, you decide it yourself. Starting off can be hard, like really hard. So hard, you probably will rage quit if you do not know what to do. The early game has bandits, Looters, Outlaws that will chase you down and take your prisoner. To counter this, you can raise an army by going to a nearby town and recruiting villagers. Note, these villagers are not good. You will have to upgrade them to win, and the start of the game will depend on you, and rarely the troops you have. There is a total of 5 different factions, and you get to choose which ones you will join, ally with, or seige war with. All the factions have different troops, weapons, and soldiers to make the game more unique. Some have better infantry, others archers, or calvery. Then you have companions which tag along side with you. They will never die, but can be wounded, upgraded, and you have the choice of what their stats will be, and what they are equipped with. Overall, companions are really good once you get them to the point where they help with fighting, and give you an additional point in skills. If they have +3 in Surgery, that will combine with your +2 to make a total of +5. They are helpful, and are recommded.Being a vassal to a kingdom is where the game starts to get intense. You get assigned a random fief(Town, castle, or a city) in which will pay you a weekly tax. Note, castles do not pay anything, only a place to store troops at and keep your council members. Being a vassal to a king, you will get to join military seiges. The marshal to the faction will send you a message to gather some troops and join him in a march to fight the enemy. If you decide to join, your relation with the faction and marshal will go up.That brings us to relationships. This can be a pain. You normally start of with your relationship with everyone set at 0. To make it go up, you will have to ask for tasks you can fulfill. Every task you take, the relationship goes up by +1, and rarely +2. Every time you get your relationship up 20 points, the lord will change relationships with you. Friend, Trustworthy, Devoted, etc. The more he likes you, the better the odds of persuasion, Marrying their daughter, owning more fiefs, and more.To own a fief, the king grants you it. They usually seek vassals without any fiefs, or their friends. That is why relationships with a lot of lords will help.Marrying a daughter to a lord will improve your status a lot. It also gives more diplomatic options in your council, which is located at your castle or small town. Note, not many women like to marry a man without a castle or city. Don't mix a City with a town. A town is a small, poor village. A city has a market, etc. To continue, to make a women like you, you will have to speek to them and click the option, "I am your admiror" or something like that. That will either benefit you, or quite the opposite. Then she will send you a letter every 7 days to come visit her. Visit her until you get a relationship of 25+, then you ask to marry her.Renown is the amount of lords that talk about you. Getting this up will help you get more known, which causes people you've never even met like you. You can get this up by fighting bandits, defeating enemies, marrying, etc.Honor affects your interactions with other lords and causes certain events. A high honor can increase the likelihood of a mercanary accepting an offer, or of you being elected as marshall. Lords will like you for having positive honor, and every 3 points in honor will increase relationships by +1. Lower honor can result in a bounty on your head, or a war being declared on your faction.Right to Rule is, well. Self explanitory. If you have a low right to rule, do not start your own faction. This will result in every kingdom to think you are an outlaw, "Not worthy enough to own a kingdom" and will declare war on you. Start your kingdom when it reached about 80.Starting your own faction is, well. Kind of easy actually. Its for a late game, when you've married, and have become lasting allies with another faction. Once you want to start your own faction, you have to go rogue. Break up your alliance with your current kingdom, and attack an enemy. Take the castle, and you will have the option to choose a flag/banner. You basically are your own king, and can hire vassals, or make your companion a vassal. To make a companion a vassal, talk to them and give them a fief. They will isntantly leave your army, make their own, and assist you in war. You can also persuade other lords into joining your own. You need to have the persuasion skill, and they need to have problems with their current king before you can have them switch over.From then on, you basically conquer all of the map. Thats very late, late end game. The overall singleplayer can last hundreds of hours, which is why this game is unique.Overall, the game is amazing, and is well worth it in my opinion, and I recommend it to everyone who loves roleplaying. Mods are very, very recomended. The base came comes flat with not many diplomatic options. I will recommend some mods for you to try, as they will enhance gameplay by a lot. I don't even play the base game anymore as it's very, blah.A Clash of KingsFloris ExpandedFull Invasion 2 (Multiplayer only)You can find them all here http://www.moddb.com/games/mount-blade-warband/mods

												I highly recommend this game for the visceral combat. It will have you moving in your chair as you try to land that perfect strike or block an enemy's. Easily the best medival PvP combat I've played so far. Better than "Vikings", "War of the Roses" and slightly better than "Chivalry". The graphics are outdated, but somehow they are good enough to get immersed, especially the castles and battlefields. I suppose the upshot of this is that it will run on virtually any computer people reading this will have.The single-player sandbox is also quite good, you can either serve a king, or cede and start your own kingdom. Single player is much easier than multi-player, especially when you've upgrades your gear and troops.If you like medival combat, sandbox gaming, PvP, and have an older computer, I highly recommend this!

												Mount and Blade:Warband is a open-world sandbox  rpg that gives you the freedom to do whatever you want at any time. Some examples of how Warband does this are: You may ally with any faction you wish so long as you have sufficient reputation.Marry a lady to increase your standing and hold feast's. Compete in tournaments to earn fame and fortune.Roam the countryside hunting bandits or become one yourself.You can raid villages for loot and plunder. You may sell your sword to the highest bidder and change allegiances on a whim.You may even start your own faction if you so wish.Variety is the primary ingredient in mount and blade. Forge your destiny with blade or diplomacy the choice is yours.Combat is the other major selling point for this title. Combat is a tense experience due to the fact that no matter how powerful you become one mistake can lead to a crushing defeat if you are careless.This title offers tons gameplay for the price you can easily sink hundreds of hours into this game. If you should ever grow tired of the gameplay simply buy a expansion that offers a whole new experience and you are good to go.

												Recruit soldiers and companions, do battle and train them up. Improve your character. Be a mercenary, a bandit, a vassal to a king or just play nice with the other lords, until you are ready to claim the crown yourself. There are no fixed goals, so you are free to set your own and that's what's so wonderful about this game.Battles however are where this game really shines. There is just something immensely satisfying about toppling knights from their horses, running down fleeing enemies and seeing enemy soldiers tumble from the walls of castles and towns. Plus, with the excellent sounds you can almost feel the arrows and bolts impacting on your shield.If you give this game the benefit of the doubt and open yourself up to its learning curve, you'll find a game unlike anything else around. Depending on your goals a game can last 80 hours and more.
