content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												New Review:Old review in the end:New:I will try to write a very objective review but its hard since i love this game.I will structure this into:a summary/review in text formPro/ConPoint listThis game doesnt have the best graphics so if you are instantly turned away by that no need to read further.BUT if you (like me) value quality gameplay over graphics you are in for a treat.If you like medieval games thats a huge pro right of the bat. This game tries to be more realistic than other games, you will not be able to run up a hill dodging arrows and kill 100 men on your own and not taking a single hit. You will not be able to defeat every enemy faction easily and within just 1hour of playing. You will not be able to cast a huge tornado to kill al your enemies. In this game you will have to fight like any other man, you will have to command your troops in somewhat of a logical tactic to achieve victory, you will have to think before running straight at an enemy. In this game you can choose whoever you want to be, you can be a cruel lord, or a kind one. you can be a hunter, or a bandit. you can become almost anythign you want. The huge sandbox enables you to live out your dreams.And once you did everything there is to do the game isnt done, you can install SO many mods that kept the game alive for so long, you can get an entireley new game for free by clicking a few buttons. if you are out for multiplayer this game is also still alive when it comes to MP.Pro/ConPro:You choose your storyHuge Open worldRealismEndless ways to playActive multiplayerActive modding communityAddictive gameplayExtremly fun combatSo much to explore and discoverMainly nice community (about 99% of the people i met were nice)Good DLC'sCon:Outdated GraphicsPoints:Graphics: 3/10Combat system: 9/10Map: 8/10Replayability: 10/10Opertunitys/options: 10/10Mods and mod support: 10/10Economy system: 6/10Price: 10/10 (100% worth it)Multiplayer 10/10Community: 9/10Realism: 8/10Freedom of coice: 10/10Total: 103/120Verdict: Extremly good and totaly worth buyingOld [with edits in ()]:Over 140 hours(now a "few" more) of gameplay show how much I like (love) this game. M&B Warband is the best RPG I know, of course the graphics are a bit old but it still is very much fun to play, you can do what you want. Travel as a lone wanderer and get money from small tasks or defeating small bandit parties OR become the greatest leader in the world, own 100 towns and command 1000 men while you take over the world. Another great thing about this game is that it is logical. You can not just charge up the hill alone dodge 1000 arrows pary 100000 sword swings and slaughter 10000000 men (slight exaduration, the game cnat place that many troops at once). You need to think before you do things, react to different situations, command your soldiers and tell them what to do. Different strategys different results. This open World RPG has endless options and oppertunities. SO stop reading reviews buy the game and ride into your destiny(wow i went total fanboy back then) !!!

												This game is perfect. It says I played 250+ hours, but I played many, many more before I used steam.You can command your own army in person and have to actually deal with the problems of logistics, food and your own gear. It's kind of a mix between Chivalry and the Total War series, you can conquer the world and manage your towns (even your vassals) but you can do it from your character's perspective. You're no longer some sort of god that watches from space on a drawed map (which is cool too, don't get me wrong). Now, one point is the graphics, they're really good for an indie game (made by a man and his wife) but you're going to need to mod it up a bit if you're a real graphics addict. The gameplay makes up for it ten times though!The mods are actually a great part of the game. You have tons of them, varying from massive overhauls which completely change the financial system and more, to mods that just add some extra gear and graphics. There is so much variety. The modding community is just huge. Some mods that I really enjoyed:- Prophesy of Pendor (complete overhaul, new map, factions, lore, units and many more)- Blood in the West (lord of the rings)- Floris mod expanded (an enchancement of the current gameplay)- Gekokujo (Samuraaaiii)It's 66% off now, BUY IT. content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												NOTE: Review based off non-steam version, playtime is not accurateMount & Blade Warband has terrible enemy AI, broken siege mechanics, very dated graphics, and is quite possibly one of the best games of it's kind.Never before have I seen a game that blends RPG and Real Time Strategy together in such a satisfying way. This is emergent gameplay at it's finest because it in no way limits you from choosing to play as you see fit. You can rise to become King of the entire world and unite them all, or undermine them all by playing them against one another in a never ending conflict, or ignore war altogether to become a trader, or a bandit, maybe even take over a castle as an illegitimate marauder and see how long you can hold out against the vast armies out to take it from you. You can travel with a huge army or a small group of interesting NPCs. Don't like the base setting? You can download mods to play in real world settings, or fantastical places like Westeros from A Song of Ice and Fire, or Middle Earth from Lord of the Rings.If you like sandbox games, this is it at it's finest. Does it have problems? Sure, of course it does. The saving grace however is that everything else works beautifully.COMBAT - While the AI is incredibly stupid to the point of just knowing basic "charge at you screaming" tactics and turning their back to a cavalry charge to chase one guy who broke through their lines first... the combat itself is very well done. Melee feels very intense and reactionary, you have to be on your guard at all times and be ready to take advantage of any enemy weaknesses. Archery is both deadly and difficult, and requires a serious investment for your character to be good at. Unit types are varied with no one faction sharing identical unit types. Mounted combat is the best I've ever seen in a game allowing you to use a large variety of weapons from horseback and giving serious advantage to mounted warriors. There's a lot I could say about combat but it's really got to be experienced first hand.POLITICS - With 6 main factions in the game, rival claimants to every throne, independent troops of bandits, raiders, deserters, and the like, and the possibility to even create your own separate faction, there is a ton of variety in the game. You can side with any of the factions or none of them, you can even play several off on each other if you have good relations with multiple lords. You can marry a huge number of eligible partners, as either male or female. You can even convince certain lords to defect to your own faction if they like you well enough. You can rise in influence by doing quests, conquering enemy settlements, capturing rival lords, and defending your faction's territory.SIEGE - Siege mechanics are a little lacking, you will only ever have one ladder (which is really a ramp) or one siege tower for any castle siege, the AI again is very basic, the archers fire from a distance but all melee and cavalry units (who dismount for the siege) just clambor up single file to the top of a wall to fight a war of numbers against a swarm of bunched together units at the top. You can issue commands to pre-defined groups (Archers, Melee, Cavalry, Etc.) to tell them where to go, what kind of weapons to use, and so on, but by and large the sieges aren't the biggest highlight though they are still incredibly intense due to awesome combat mechanics.ROLEPLAY - While there is an element of backstory and lore to this world, mostly explored through your companion's musings on areas, by and large the world is very open for interpretation. The six factions are based off real-world equivalents like the Cossacks, Mongols, Arabs, Vikings, and Gauls both in terms of unit types and archtitecture. Roleplaying shines however in how it allows you to be whoever you want to be. You can choose to start as a lord with enough honor to have your own banner sigil, or start as a lowly thief who just runs about burning villages and trying to keep one step ahead of the law as you try and make it rich. There's so many variables that let you choose how to play the game, you can even solo the game if you want for a true challenge. There are a lot of unique stats and skills you upgrade independently that affect everything from your persuasion attemps, battle tactics, map speed, weapon skill, and the size of your army.ACTIVITIES - Aside from combat, there are quest opportunities available in villages, towns, and from other lords who ask favors. There's maybe only 10 types of quests, that range from delivering trade goods, cattle steering, bandit hunting, village defense, soldier training, attacking enemy settlements, or capturing rival lords. In addition to this there are arenas and tournaments that allow you to bet on yourself as you fight in a host of games. Upgrading buildings in towns and villages you own. Exploring towns and castles. Attending feasts. Recruiting and training units. There's always SOMETHING to do.Bottom line, if you haven't played this game yet and you are even remotely interested in RPGs or RTSs then you need to get it now!

Posted: July 1, 2014
												Buy this game if you have no wish to be a productive human being. Once you get over the butt ugly interface the game sucks you in with its extremely satisfying combat (Imagine charging past an archer on your steed, swinging your sword low and hearing the sickening crunch of sword on flesh followed by a strangled scream... ). But beneath the seemingly simple combat is a layer of complexity that is intiutive and easy to grasp. 4 Directions to block and 4 directions to attack from, with speed and direction of attack factoring in for bonuses or penalties (hit a man on the helmet, you'll give him a bad headache, hit him just under his chin where cloth meets skin and he'll crumple at your feet). The combat is only a single layer that makes up this game. It's like a cake, and each of it's layers offers fresh challenges and experiences filled with sweetness and delight. From troop management to merchantilism to politicing and ruling kingdoms. Every layer is complementary to each other, but can be approached individually at your own pace. Obviously things like ruling requires a solid understanding of how each of the other systems work. And once your in a position to wage war against a neighbouring kingdom things begin to snowball, like sitting a final exam it will test your experience in all avenues of the game's layers.Live your game of thrones fantasies with this game ...at least until season 5 is out.

												Absolutely phenomenal game, for a game that was made a while ago to be so in depth and have so much polish, will continued support and new mods consistently is impressive. I don't know exactly what to detail so i'll make this brief.Pros:- Price: You'd be a fool to not buy this for such a cheap price, it's really that simple.- Hitboxes: I can stand behind a wall of infantry and let arrows fly right next to fellow soldiers heads and not hit them, it's something that doesn't even happen in lots of AAA games these days.- Hit Detection and Ragdoll: If you cut a soldiers face, he will hold his face and collapse, if you cut behind his legs he will collapse onto his knees and then die.- Challenge: I made a female character because the game said it might be more of a challenge and I love it. slowly working your way up and earning the trust of fellow lords and gaining your own townships and/or castles is immensely fun.Cons:- Variety: I could be wrong on this one but sometimes I run out of things to do, the quests you receive from guild masters in towns can get boring and repetitive, I find wartime is my favourite time, you can earn so much money and I love ambushing opposing lords when they are weak. - Lack of Co-Op? Again this is a bit of an open ended, it would make this game a 10/10 if there was a way to have a similar experience with a mate rather than just battling in MP. Nothing more to say, this game has incredible depth for a game released so long ago, and if someone asks you why you're a part of the PC Master Race, point them to the steam workshop.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Great power-grab simulator. If you always wanted to sit on a throne in some high castle hall, and to put yourself there by physically killing people, this is the game to do it. Decent military tactics game too, though the troop commands could be better laid-out and could also be more numerous. The lack of any ability to pre-plan before battles can be annoying too, when you have to do it manually on the battlefield through command setting in real-time. Really, I think the saving grace of this game is the Module system, and ultimately, a lot of what you're buying is access to the launcher and files. There's vanilla-improvement mods in pretty solid supply (I recommend Silverstag, a newer project that fixes a lot of my gripes with vanilla and is just overall super good), but there's also lots of total conversion mods, many of which being created by history fanatics to accurately recreate whatever time-period they're interested in, so that's super cool. As far as vanilla multiplayer goes, it's tough, there's no auto-block or auto-lance-couching that I've seen, and it can be super fun if you can get to a point where you aren't just feeing the killcount of better players the whole time.RATINGSGraphics: 7/10Feels like 2006. Scope of the game, price and budget pretty much justifies it, but still ugly. Some mods also improve it, so there's that. However, the design work is quite good, and armor/weapons are recreated fairly faithfully to real-world history, though they may not have all existed at the same time, I don't know for sure.Combat: 7/10Klunky, but satisfying in its brutality. Good weapon variety, 4 attacks and 4 blocks to match them, lance couching, etc... shields are strong, but breakable and tied to a skill, pretty cool stuff. But can be very frustrating, with enemies able to attack through each other very often and also attack/block matching making fighting more than one enemy at a time quite difficult.Replayability: 10/10Combination of mods and different possibilites with factions/roleplaying/character setup make for good replay value. Plus, multiplayer.Value for cost: 9/10The game provides a good amount of gameplay alone, but again, mods really improve the value dramatically. The DLCs are just paid-for mods not so much bigger than user-created ones though, so that costs a point, I think.Strategy gameplay: 8/10Can strategize, but dominant strategies exist in terms of troop types/proportions in vanilla, and it's hard to make good use of some units. Cavalry, for example, constantly make poor use of their lances and their speed advantage, and has absolutely terrible AI once they stop moving, which happens a lot since they're bad at avoiding getting bogged down in infantry crowds. This is the only reason I can see for why the Swadians lose fights against Nords so often.OTHER NOTES/TIPS IN CASE YOU BUY ITThe game will default to easymode, so you may want to increase it once you've gotten yourself started. however, this is set this way for a reason. "normal" player damage, for example, means instantly dying to just about any damage at all at low levels, and is extremely frustrating. Just raise the difficulty as you progress and can handle it, at least the first time through the game.Also, upon starting a new character, the game asks about saving policy. I strongly suggest "allow me to quit without saving". Things beyond your control can ♥♥♥♥ you up very easily, and make a game miserable if you can't reload. For example, being crushed by three separate parties of steppe bandits all combined into one because you didn't know how fast they are. That happened instantly the first time I ever entered khergit land.I personally recommend starting with the Nords, Swadians or Rhodoks. Swadians especially have lots of bandits, and a strong tendency towards wars due to its central position, so it's great for rapidly improving. Rhodoks are well-defended and rarely lose much actual property, and Nords are just really strong for siege infantry and their outlaws aren't as hardcore as Khergit, Vaegir or Sarranid outlaws (the same is true of the more numerous swadian bandits, though.)Don't try to be a horse archer unless you mean it. It takes a ton of skill and proficiency point allotment to be a good one and it's really not worth it besides for roleplay value.Attend tournaments as often as possible. Ask arena masters where they're being held every time you visit a town, especially early on.Don't be afraid to try to retreat. It's better than being defeated and imprisoned, and any morale losses can be smoothed over by killing some bandits and buying some extra food.That's my review! Enjoy the game if you buy it.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												As a predecessor expansion to the Mount and Blade series. Warband's hearty and distracting gameplay will take the mechanics of large scale medieval combat and place the power in the Players keyboard and mouse. A game that takes the combat mechanics to a well thought out directional system that includes feints, chambers and a blocking system blended with the attack system dependent on your weapon of choice. Sorry, no magic to be found here.Rise from peasantry and become a Lord within a faction' or crush all who would stand against you.The Game provides a decent amount of follow up mechanics to assist in your conquest.In addition to the well worked combat system, mechanics like Reknown which will increase your troop count as well as your individuals recognition together with Right to Rule that will draw the famous swords from the Calradia to your vasslage with each victory.The game may not look great but what Warband lacks in looks it makes up for in replay value and addicting combat escapades.In addition, the modding community behind this game has taken many strides.One alternative to the standard Warband mode that I've personally found the most value and entertainment has come from cRPG, found at c-rpg.net, c-RPG and it's soon to be predecessor Melee: Battlegrounds takes the campaign elements of combat and provides server space to continue that campaign on a greater scale with your friends in a Round-by-round series known as Strategus.However, now your character is your community representative, become a hero, become a villain, or become a troll. Your influence brings a special part to a somewhat-scummy but enjoyable community. TL;DR: Warband for its age is still great and worth its weight in any countries e-moneys. Please, enjoy its mods, communities, and overall enjoyable experience. Have fun.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2013
												Mount and blade warband is a unique game. You will find non other like it. It has potential to be great, and it does just that, but there are a few things you should note before deciding to pick it up yourself. I will tell you everything I know, as I've played countless hours of the game and basically achieved everything you can learn within the game. So, lets get started.First off, the game will be confusing if you have just started. You think there is a campaign, quests, or something to guide you? There is not. You have the power to go wherever you want, join whatever you want, and be whoever you want. The game does not decide anything for you, you decide it yourself. Starting off can be hard, like really hard. So hard, you probably will rage quit if you do not know what to do. The early game has bandits, Looters, Outlaws that will chase you down and take your prisoner. To counter this, you can raise an army by going to a nearby town and recruiting villagers. Note, these villagers are not good. You will have to upgrade them to win, and the start of the game will depend on you, and rarely the troops you have. There is a total of 5 different factions, and you get to choose which ones you will join, ally with, or seige war with. All the factions have different troops, weapons, and soldiers to make the game more unique. Some have better infantry, others archers, or calvery. Then you have companions which tag along side with you. They will never die, but can be wounded, upgraded, and you have the choice of what their stats will be, and what they are equipped with. Overall, companions are really good once you get them to the point where they help with fighting, and give you an additional point in skills. If they have +3 in Surgery, that will combine with your +2 to make a total of +5. They are helpful, and are recommded.Being a vassal to a kingdom is where the game starts to get intense. You get assigned a random fief(Town, castle, or a city) in which will pay you a weekly tax. Note, castles do not pay anything, only a place to store troops at and keep your council members. Being a vassal to a king, you will get to join military seiges. The marshal to the faction will send you a message to gather some troops and join him in a march to fight the enemy. If you decide to join, your relation with the faction and marshal will go up.That brings us to relationships. This can be a pain. You normally start of with your relationship with everyone set at 0. To make it go up, you will have to ask for tasks you can fulfill. Every task you take, the relationship goes up by +1, and rarely +2. Every time you get your relationship up 20 points, the lord will change relationships with you. Friend, Trustworthy, Devoted, etc. The more he likes you, the better the odds of persuasion, Marrying their daughter, owning more fiefs, and more.To own a fief, the king grants you it. They usually seek vassals without any fiefs, or their friends. That is why relationships with a lot of lords will help.Marrying a daughter to a lord will improve your status a lot. It also gives more diplomatic options in your council, which is located at your castle or small town. Note, not many women like to marry a man without a castle or city. Don't mix a City with a town. A town is a small, poor village. A city has a market, etc. To continue, to make a women like you, you will have to speek to them and click the option, "I am your admiror" or something like that. That will either benefit you, or quite the opposite. Then she will send you a letter every 7 days to come visit her. Visit her until you get a relationship of 25+, then you ask to marry her.Renown is the amount of lords that talk about you. Getting this up will help you get more known, which causes people you've never even met like you. You can get this up by fighting bandits, defeating enemies, marrying, etc.Honor affects your interactions with other lords and causes certain events. A high honor can increase the likelihood of a mercanary accepting an offer, or of you being elected as marshall. Lords will like you for having positive honor, and every 3 points in honor will increase relationships by +1. Lower honor can result in a bounty on your head, or a war being declared on your faction.Right to Rule is, well. Self explanitory. If you have a low right to rule, do not start your own faction. This will result in every kingdom to think you are an outlaw, "Not worthy enough to own a kingdom" and will declare war on you. Start your kingdom when it reached about 80.Starting your own faction is, well. Kind of easy actually. Its for a late game, when you've married, and have become lasting allies with another faction. Once you want to start your own faction, you have to go rogue. Break up your alliance with your current kingdom, and attack an enemy. Take the castle, and you will have the option to choose a flag/banner. You basically are your own king, and can hire vassals, or make your companion a vassal. To make a companion a vassal, talk to them and give them a fief. They will isntantly leave your army, make their own, and assist you in war. You can also persuade other lords into joining your own. You need to have the persuasion skill, and they need to have problems with their current king before you can have them switch over.From then on, you basically conquer all of the map. Thats very late, late end game. The overall singleplayer can last hundreds of hours, which is why this game is unique.Overall, the game is amazing, and is well worth it in my opinion, and I recommend it to everyone who loves roleplaying. Mods are very, very recomended. The base came comes flat with not many diplomatic options. I will recommend some mods for you to try, as they will enhance gameplay by a lot. I don't even play the base game anymore as it's very, blah.A Clash of KingsFloris ExpandedFull Invasion 2 (Multiplayer only)You can find them all here http://www.moddb.com/games/mount-blade-warband/mods

												This game was the reason I became a PC gamer. Before being introduced to this game I was a console fanboy and played minecraft on occassion. It was not until I was introduced to this game that I fully understood what was all possible. I started off by joining a regiment in Napoleonic Wars called 34e. This regiment stayed active for I think around 6 months or some where near that. It was some of my best experiences to date. I met friends in that unit and through this game that I have played with ever since. After NW was overplayed for myself, I switched to Persistent World. That brought a whole new world of possiblities. Learning about medieval times in history and actually participating in it was a whole new experience. It allowed me to act out what had always interested me, along with allowing me to join some factions to ultimately meet some pretty amazing people. I have spent maybe 400 hours playing NW, 500 hours playing PW if not more, and around 100 hours for native. While this game lacks some graphic capabilities, the game play makes up for it all. If you are even remotely interested in history or fantasy games/movies I would recommend this game and the thousands of mods out there ready for consumption. All and all, amazing game and cannot wait till bannerlord.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Mount and Blade: Warband is an Action RPG with Kingdom Sim elements that drops you into the land of Calradia, a low fantasy land of feudal nations warring for supremacy. It is readily apparent that Sid Meier's Pirates! served as a primary inspiration for this game, as it plays like a more combat oriented version with a medieval setting instead.To get the negatives out of the way, I'll start by mentioning the low production values. As the screenshots betray, this isn't the most beautiful game out there. There is little voice acting, and what is there does not stand out as memorable. The interface design is spartan and pragmatic, with little in the way of flourish. There are strange design choices (such as siege battles that only have one ladder for the attackers to climb) that can result in an unbalanced play experience. However, if you are the type of gamer that values new and compelling experiences above production values then you will be hard pressed to find a game that fills this niche better than Mount and Blade: Warband. You start by creating a character through a series of basic background choices that determine starting stat values as well as equipment and other odds and ends. You are then unceremoniously dropped into the land of Calradia, with the world your oyster. You can go around recruiting volunteers to fight as a mercenary band, fight in tournaments for money and presitge, and eventually become a vassal to a king or even start your own faction. There are a lot of systems at play, and it would be difficult to condense them into this review. The main draw for many players, however, is the sizable amount of quality mods available thanks to the passionate fan community surrounding the game. Once you've got your fill of the vanilla game, you have a large choice of mods that expand the game in many different directions, such as fleshing out the kingdom management aspect with new diplomacy options, the ability to play as a common foot soldier in a Lord's army, and even total conversions that transport the game into both original worlds and those from licensed properties. As you can see, I fully recommend this game to anyone that is tempted by anything you read in both this review and the others. If you still aren't convinced, you can visit the TaleWorlds website and download the trial game to get a feel for it and see if it's something you'd be into. The trial features everything the full game does, just with a level cap, so you can try different things and see if something clicks.

												I think it's the most perfect medieval game on the market. Mount&Blade is....well, what is it?? It's an RPG, that's one thing it is, and feels sandboxy a bit, in the good way. It's an RTS, but it also makes your character apart of the action as a commander, or whatever you want. I'd say it's accurate to call it a Medieval simulator too. Mount&Blade is probably one of those games which I longed to play for years but never knew about. When I found out, I was enthralled, BEWILDERED!! I loved it more than I thought I would and can easily wrack up hours playing it. Field battles, sieges, RTS-like map, your own RPG character put into it all. The combat system is my favorite thing about it, and the multiplayer element Warband gives has become a replacement to the time spent on my favorite FPS games.GET WARBAND. It is NOT an expansion and you do no need Mount&Blade #1 to play it. It has literally everything M&B has, along with everything you wish it had. PLAY THIS GAME PLZ!Furthermore, the game has an extremely wonderful community on the developer (Taleworlds) forums. These forums also has a HUGE list of full-conversion to small mods. A singleplayer game in Warband can take anywhere from around 100 to 150 hours (if you rush it, that is). The mods will extend that tenfold. Bored of Medieval? Turn it into the old west. Or the British Isles in the Dark Ages. There is so much time and joy Warband will give you especially with these mods. As well as captivating multiplayer. Not convinced about Warband? I encourage you to read lots of reviews where I could not do it justice, and PLAY IT!! I don't know what the demo is, whether it's lame or not, but maybe you can give that a try too.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												It all started with a random Steam sale. 5 dollars. All it took to bind me forever to a game. I can no longer escape. Send help immediately. If you are vulnerable to extremely awesome game, stay away. It will consume you, as it consumed my life (the social one).With all the choices I was given at the start, I somehow knew I wanted to be a street urchin who grew up as a wild animal hunter  (despite the temptation of being a lord). I roamed the land filled with bandits and rogue soldiers, hunting animals and four legged creatures alike. I could tell my character was becoming more attuned with the bow. Despite being a commoner, my fame rose rapidly across the land. Many maidens learnt of my skill with the bow. Some told of my tale; a band of handful horse riding archers that took down an army of 100. Two dozen bowmen that fortified a castle against marauding band of 1000 mountain bandits. Ferocious but merciful enough to allow cowards to save their lives. Ambitious but honorable enough to release held captives. It was around this time when the King of Swadia sent one of his vassal to invite me to the royal castle. Despite the base birth, I was knighted to lordship. With every feast held at a castle, many lords suggested kinship through marriage. Through a marriage, I attained a position third to the King. With little bit of planning, the devious wife was able to plot a downfall of the second in command, leaving me to assume the position. I was now leading a standing army of 1500 against the filthy Nords. Campaign after campaign, I wiped all opposing sovereigns on the map. On the next playthrough, I chose a noble birth. I was inducted under a king much, much quicker. I have over 500 hours clocked in and yet I still haven't done much. This game is a drug. Stay away if you cannot fight addiction. That being said,BUY THIS GAME NOW12 out of 10.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												You start from nothing in this cold, harsh, and whimsical fuedal land. You scavenge whatever meager profits you can by attacking looters and hobbling from town to town, recruiting young farm hands in need of adventure or work. Your party is growing now, and you've become someone of a local hero to all the townspeople you save from looters. Wether you are in it for glory, honor, or wealth is unimportant, as you forge your own story. You ride onwards to a major city, a tournament is being held! You shrug, as you've nothing to lose, and enter the grand battle in hopes of achieveing wealth, reknown, and glory! Beaten and battered, you are the champion of this day, and have earned a nice sum of wealth to your name. You speak to a King of one of the 7 factions, as you are welcomed to join in his feast for being the champion of the tournament. You are in need of work, as you can't slay looters forever, and crave something more, possibly kingship one day. You swear vassalage to the king, and ride onwards with newfound passion. Your warband grows even larger. Relationships are shattered, men are slain, villages are sacked, and great cities fall. War continues to ravage the countryside as you ride now amongst your king and his many vassals across the land. You take many lands and prove your worth to the king, he grants you fiefs and honor, but you know this close relationship you hold with him cannot be sustained. You speak to one of your companions, and tell them to ride far, far off into distant lands, spouting tales of your glory, and how you long to be king. You continue to grow in power. You scheme, speaking with rivals from other factions, improving relations with them and tearing their loyalty away from their liege and towards you. You bide your time, until finally you strike! You speak with your king, and tell him that you wish to break away and pursue other goals. The king is saddened, but respects your decision. You are stripped of your lands. Soon, you besiege an undefended castle that belonged to your former king's faction. You take it with ease, and forge your own faction in the fires of war. Soon, your faction grows, lords from all over pledge to be vassals for your cause, you will unite Calradia! Eventually, you face your former king, and friend, in open combat. You cross blades, and you notice that a tear comes to his eye. You incapacitate him, and let him leave with his honor when the battle is over. Years pass, and after seeing many men slain, Calradia is finally united under your rule. You've done shameful things. You done honorable deeds. You've loved. You've lost. You've killed many men in pursuit of a goal. This was your story. This, was your warband.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
												This game is a gem. It's single player campaign is highly immersive. In the Kingdom of Calradia there is 6 factions, each representing an area of the Medieval world (Italians, Arabs, etc) .You start as a individual with a backstory decided by you and a character who's stats and looks(to the nose and eyebrow size) are decided by you.Beginning as the leader of a small warrior band, your military grows in size as you seize control of towns and castles and train your peasant recruits into elite warriors that can tear through enemies like medieval tanks. Eventually you will be able to conquer Caldaria alongside your Noble King or start your own Kingdom and conquer the land yourself.Little touches like interactive companions with very interesting backstories and have complex relationships with your other companions increases the feel of immersion. The game's modding community is incredibly powerful allowing for an endless stream of new content.The Multi-player is simply epic, especially with the Napoleonic DLC. The game has developed a community of "regiments" that partake in historical linebattles. These linebattles are heavily strategic and exciting as you are always given a single life.Melee combat is simple to learn but hard to master. You direct your weapon to body parts with the mouse and block with the mouse. Engagements are exciting and there is a huge variety of modes, from large battles, duels to even great sieges. The game's servers have high player limits, 64-200 leading to epic battles.A gem and considering the price, a MUST HAVE.

												Extremely good game. A feudal/medieval society simulator that never feels too shallow and never feels too complicated.   PROS  -Simulation aspects are well-balanced with gameplay.  -Combat feels very nice.  -Many ways to play. You can play as a merchant, bandit, loyal vassal, mercenary, and many others.  -Every game system and mechanic feels extremely developed, well-thought-out and substantial.-Many, many hours of gameplay. It completely sucks you in.   CONS  -Battles lack strategic depth. You can shout orders at your troops, but these orders are extremely limited, so battles always devolve into chaotic mass of AI soldiers whacking each other until the other side is dead.  -Very outdated graphics.  -UI can get pretty annoying.  Would highly, highly recommend. One of my favorite games. If Bannerlord (the next, upcoming game in the series) fixes the battles and UI, it will be an almost perfect game.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												I've been playing this game since the day it came out, which is why it only shows 2 hours; I only just activated it on Steam a couple days ago!  But make no mistake; I've played this game for hundreds upon hundreds of hours over years and years of my life.  My first experience with the franchise was actually with the original M&B, when it was still in a very early beta back in 2007!  Unfortunately, my CD key for the original doesn't seem to work on Steam, mais, c'est la vie.  But, yes; I love this game.  The best and the first First-Person Slasher out there.  Good modding community from the start, too; though the selection in the Steam workshop is limited.  A good mod to try, btw, is Floris; you'll need to go online to find it, though.  Also, IT HAS NATIVE LINUX SUPPORT NOW!!  That litterally made my life.  Hell, I would have bought the game again just to play it on Linux, if my CD key hadn't been activatable on Steam.  It's that good.  Sure, the graphics are quite lacking, and the quests are all pretty much the same; but that's okay, because the combat system is so good that you won't care.  There are, however, no gay marriages in vanilla; so, if you want that sort of thing, you'll need a mod.  Floris, btw, will let you do this (as well as optionally remove or increase the level of sexism in the game; but the main focus of it is on general game improvement).  If you're waiting for the new installment in the series, Bannerlord, to come out, rather than buying this game; you should be buying this game while you wait.  And if you're coming to WB from the original, the faction colours are a bit different, when it doesn't make any sense for them to be; you'll get used to them quickly, though.  Everything else is a nice step-up from the first game.

There is a hell of a lot to do in this game and that's why I love it. Its not a strategy game yet there's still a challenge in making certain decisions and it's not a slow pasted game either. The main reason though I would have to say this game is so great is the satisfaction you get from creating your own army and fighting on the battlefield with them and winning. The more men your have, the more badass you feel, the more likely you will want to create stories of your character and how you have not been defeated. But be carefull, you can go from an undefeated army to a one man in chains being taken prisoner by your enemy. This game is worth the buy.

												This Review is of Napoleonic Wars only. Mount and Blade warband is however an amazing game and you should get it. This contains all events that I have experienced in my time playing this game and I may update it to add new events as I see fit.Day 1I begin my first day of service in a Prussian castle. The Austrians have come to take our castle and it is up to my team and I to stop them. There is seventy of us charging out to the front lines and over 100 Austrian bots controlled by five player commanders.The Austrians prepare to fire and take around thirteen of us down right away. My friends and I quickly scuttle behind a hill with some other team mates. We get ready to fire and climb the hill slowly. As our upper torsos peak over the hill three of us go down as the remaining two fire and both miss. Damn.Day 2My friends and I walk out of the castle once again and see the right flank being overrun and our artillery being charged. We instantly run to the rescue, sucessfully pushing back the Austrian ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in a bloody massacre. Planting the Prussian flag we show the Austrians that this is our land and we will fight to our last breaths for it.Day 3It is the dead of night. My division has been moved to defend a small fort across a river from a small village. We hear the Austrians begin their march and the battle begins. My friends and I take to horses, slashing down Austrians as we ride through the field, dodging musket fire. The battle rages through the night and in the morning we come out victorious.Day 4My division has been ordered to fight and finish the last of the Austrian army. My friend and I march in line behind our comrades following our commander. As we march I am shot down but not killed. My friend continues marching as our numbers continuously fall. Eventually Austrian cavalry charge our remaining forces and my friend suffers a panic attack and is one of the first to fall. We both now have PTSD and he has developped a fear of horses.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2013
												I have thought long about recommending this game, which I played for three years.So, here we go. Mount&Blade: Warband comes along with Single and Multiplay mode.Single Player is easily explained: you start out with a rusty blade and a horse. After that you work yourself up from the very bottom of the feudal society to the top. You can become Emperor of Calradia, so, are you ready to accomplish it?If that is not enough, you can choose one of these tons of mods, which were created for this game. There is something that will fit your taste. They add so much to the game, it's incredible.The Multiplayer mode is great. There is no other adjective to describe it, I spent over 2000 hours of my life on Multiplayer alone. The skill level, which you can achieve, is fairly comparable to Counter Strike, Warcraft, Starcraft, Dota, League of Legends or any other major eSports title. Mount&Blade Warband comes along with an unique melee fighting system, which allows a lot of moves, tactics and all that other stuff you expect. Various game modes increase the replayability of Multiplayer, although Duel, Siege and Battle would be fairly enough to keep you playing, once you grasped the spirit of this game, for months or like me, for years. What increases the value of multiplayer again is the fact that this game is kept alive by the community, which developed an active competetive scene with tournaments, leagues and clans.There are also mods for Multiplayer, with the DLC Napoleonic Wars and cRPG being by far the most popular.All in all, if you've got the guts to climb the learning wall this game has, it will provide you with an incredible amount of fun, replayability and, probably, addiction.Mount&Blade franchise games are often reduced, so you can grab them for not much money.Good luck.

												This review comes a little late but it is worth writing a helpful one. Let me tell you the story of Sir Efra, a lord of mass axtravagance and carries a lust for fame. Lord Efra was dignified by the start and in a few months was well represented by all houses of the Calradian houses. This man, with a well complexion and a well groomed beard was had received a message by the Kingdom of the Rhodoks, a faction of green and kettle heads in the north. Efra  headed with his band of well-trained Swadians up into the lands and of the North. he never stayed long and was off on his own with his band of 400 hardened and stout men to fight alongside the Rhodoks. After spilling the land of the Khergits with their own blood, despising every arrow that was let fly, he dominated the deserts of the Saranids and was awarded Unduzaq castle. Sir Efra was known for many plights of victory in the snowy lands of the Vagiers and with a single army, conquered 2 of their castle in the steep valleys. Soon, war took its toll and a vigorous fight broke out between the Rhodoks and the Kingdom of Swadia. Swadia was vast and halted the expanding Rhodoks from gaining lands in the oasis of Sarranid deserts and dunes. Sir Efra was up to the challenge and showed mercy upon the other well groomed mustaches of Swadian decent. Sir Efra was known for his trickery in the Battle of Two Kings where Efra defeated King Harlaus and the Sheriff of the Swadian Empire along the hills of the Swadian East. Dressed in a mere turban and cape, he marched into Praven and with a single pole,  helped a Sarranid Lord get back to his lady. Soon after, a warring party led by King Harlaus met on the mountain of the land by Praven as Efra's army was celebrating the daring act and met face to face with Harlaus and 4 lords of high rank. Efra fought valiantly and with his troops, caped with the blood of their enemies, were later defeated. Later dubbed, King Efra, he nade for the lands of the North with as many men as would follow him and made way for venegance.

												It all started with a random Steam sale. 5 dollars. All it took to bind me forever to a game. I can no longer escape. Send help immediately. If you are vulnerable to extremely awesome game, stay away. It will consume you, as it consumed my life (the social one).With all the choices I was given at the start, I somehow knew I wanted to be a street urchin who grew up as a wild animal hunter  (despite the temptation of being a lord). I roamed the land filled with bandits and rogue soldiers, hunting animals and four legged creatures alike. I could tell my character was becoming more attuned with the bow. Despite being a commoner, my fame rose rapidly across the land. Many maidens learnt of my skill with the bow. Some told of my tale; a band of handful horse riding archers that took down an army of 100. Two dozen bowmen that fortified a castle against marauding band of 1000 mountain bandits. Ferocious but merciful enough to allow cowards to save their lives. Ambitious but honorable enough to release held captives. It was around this time when the King of Swadia sent one of his vassal to invite me to the royal castle. Despite the base birth, I was knighted to lordship. With every feast held at a castle, many lords suggested kinship through marriage. Through a marriage, I attained a position third to the King. With little bit of planning, the devious wife was able to plot a downfall of the second in command, leaving me to assume the position. I was now leading a standing army of 1500 against the filthy Nords. Campaign after campaign, I wiped all opposing sovereigns on the map. On the next playthrough, I chose a noble birth. I was inducted under a king much, much quicker. I have over 500 hours clocked in and yet I still haven't done much. This game is a drug. Stay away if you cannot fight addiction. That being said,BUY THIS GAME NOW12 out of 10.

Posted: October 20, 2014
												Amazing game. Unique and extremely rewarding combat, simple to learn. With some training you can become an expert soldier who can turn the tide of any battle... or a military master who can overcome superior armies only with strategy.Diplomacy and quests in this game are handled in a very unique way. You can do many things to rise in power:Will you be a wealthy merchant who trades items all over Calradia?Or perhaps a mercenary who aspires to be a vassal someday and survive the schemes and struggles for power of the nobility?If those two options are not appealing to you, you can become a bandit and eventually claim your own kingdom by the sword.Finally, if you feel like you can't choose any of those options don't worry because there's no set path. You can be all these things at once if you're clever and careful. Once you master this game, use mods for a greater challenge or simply to change the environment. From Ancient Greece to the Holy Crusades, from Europe during WWII to the Middle Earth during the Third Age, modders in this game have made a great work enhancing the already great experience that Mount and Blade has to offer.Finally, if the AI isn't enough for you anymore, try the online mode, where an active community of seasoned veterans await you to siege castles, capture flags, duel, battle or fight in a deathmatch.There is more to that game than the features explained in this review. Find out for yourself, you won't regret it.Have fun.
